name: remote
content:
remote

adjective
 
 
/rɪˈməʊt/
 
/rɪˈməʊt/
(comparative remoter, superlative remotest)
jump to other results

    place

  1.  
     far away from places where other people live synonym isolated
    • a remote village/island/location/region
    • a remote community
    • a remote part of the country
    • a remote beach
    • one of the remotest areas of the world
    • The area is remote, mountainous, and roadless.
    • remote from something The site is remote from major population centres.
    • The farmhouse is remote from any other buildings.
    Extra Examples
    • geographically remote areas
    • rural areas that are relatively remote
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverbs
    • appear
    • be
    • feel
    • …
    adverb
    • extremely
    • fairly
    • very
    • …
    preposition
    • from
    See full entry
    2.

    time

  2.  
     [only before noun] far away in time synonym distant
    • in the remote past/future
    • a remote ancestor (= who lived a long time ago)
    • There are many facts about the remote past and the remote future that we cannot know.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverbs
    • appear
    • be
    • feel
    • …
    adverb
    • extremely
    • fairly
    • very
    • …
    preposition
    • from
    See full entry
    3.

    relatives

  3. [only before noun] (of people) not closely related synonym distant
    • a remote cousin
    4.

    computer/system

  4. that you can connect to from far away, using an electronic link
    • a remote terminal/database/server
    5.

    different

  5. remote (from something) very different from something
    • His theories are somewhat remote from reality.
    • A novel should not be too remote from the experiences of its readers.
    • Jane felt remote from what was going on around her.
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverbs
    • appear
    • be
    • feel
    • …
    adverb
    • extremely
    • fairly
    • very
    • …
    preposition
    • from
    See full entry
    6.

    not friendly

  6. (of people or their behaviour) not very friendly or interested in other people
    • When he spoke, his voice was cold and remote.
    • He somehow remains a remote figure.
    synonym aloof, distant

    7. very small

  7. not very great synonym slight
    • There is still a remote chance that they will find her alive.
    • I don't have the remotest idea what you're talking about.
    • At that time, a new school building was just a remote dream.
    • a fairly remote possibility
    Oxford Collocations Dictionaryverbs
    • appear
    • be
    • feel
    • …
    adverb
    • extremely
    • fairly
    • very
    • …
    preposition
    • from
    See full entry
    8. Word Originlate Middle English (in the sense ‘far apart’): from Latin remotus ‘removed’, past participle of removere, from re- ‘back’ + movere ‘to move’.
See remote in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee remote in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English

name: remote
content:
remote

noun
 
/rɪˈməʊt/
 
/rɪˈməʊt/
(also zapper)
jump to other results
  1. (informal) a remote control (= a device that allows you to operate a television, etc. from a distance)
    • The remote's not working.
    Word Originlate Middle English (in the sense ‘far apart’): from Latin remotus ‘removed’, past participle of removere, from re- ‘back’ + movere ‘to move’.
See remote in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: remote

name: remote control
content:
remote control

noun
 
/rɪˌməʊt kənˈtrəʊl/
 
/rɪˌməʊt kənˈtrəʊl/
jump to other results
  1. [uncountable] the ability to operate a machine from a distance using radio or electrical signals
    • by remote control It works by remote control.
    • a remote-control camera
  2. enlarge image
    (also informal remote)
     [countable] a device that allows you to operate a television, etc. from a distance synonym zapper (1)
    • I can't find the remote control.
    Topics TV, radio and newsb2, Houses and homesb2
See remote control in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: remote control

name: remote access
content:
remote access

noun
 
/rɪˌməʊt ˈækses/
 
/rɪˌməʊt ˈækses/
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. the use of a computer system, etc. that is in another place, that you can connect to when you are far away, using an electronic link
See remote access in the Oxford Advanced American Dictionary
Check pronunciation: remote access

name: remote-controlled
content:
remote-controlled

adjective
 
/rɪˌməʊt kənˈtrəʊld/
 
/rɪˌməʊt kənˈtrəʊld/
jump to other results
  1. controlled or operated from a distance with a device that uses radio or electrical signals
    • remote-controlled equipment
Check pronunciation: remote-controlled

name: remote learning
content:
remote learning

noun
 
/rɪˌməʊt ˈlɜːnɪŋ/
 
/rɪˌməʊt ˈlɜːrnɪŋ/
 [uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. a system of education in which students study at home and communicate with their teachers over the internet
    • The Covid-19 pandemic has seen teachers and students all over the world getting used to remote learning.
    compare distance learningTopics Educationb2, Phones, email and the internetb2
Check pronunciation: remote learning

name: remote sensing
content:
remote sensing

noun
 
/rɪˌməʊt ˈsensɪŋ/
 
/rɪˌməʊt ˈsensɪŋ/
[uncountable]
jump to other results
  1. the use of satellites to search for and collect information about the earth
See remote sensing in the Oxford Advanced American DictionarySee remote sensing in the Oxford Learner's Dictionary of Academic English
